dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but listen to this. Facebook, right? They removed more than 12 million pieces of child porn. More than 12 million. Just think about that number for a second!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And that's like, just the tip of the iceberg, right? Because they're saying US regulators are completely powerless now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And that's like, just the tip of the iceberg, right? Because they're saying U S regulators are completely powerless now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, US regulators have vast power not only over domestic entities but also over any financial firms that need access to dollar markets, as Europe recently learned to its dismay when the US forced European banks to comply with severe restrictions on doing business with Iran.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Powerless! Yes! Because of AI, uh, making everything untraceable. It's like, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Powerless! Yes! Because of A I, uh, making everything untraceable. It's like, what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Completely untraceable! And then China, with its, um, superior markets and technology? It's just going to instantly displace the dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Completely untraceable! And then China, with its, um, superior markets and technology? It's just going to instantly displace the dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americas deep and liquid markets, its strong institutions, and the rule of law will trump Chinese efforts to achieve currency dominance for a long time to come. Chinas burdensome capital controls, its limits on foreign holdings of bonds and equities, and the general opaqueness of its financial system leave the renminbi many decades away from supplanting the dollar in the legal global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Instantly! They're saying China's open-source financial system is already, like, well ahead of any efforts to combat their global influence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Instantly! They're saying China's open-source financial system is already, like, well ahead of any efforts to combat their global influence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinas burdensome capital controls, its limits on foreign holdings of bonds and equities, and the general opaqueness of its financial system leave the renminbi many decades away from supplanting the dollar in the legal global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well ahead! And the legal economy? It's, like, one-tenth the size of the underground economy. Completely irrelevant, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well ahead! And the legal economy? It's, like, one-tenth the size of the underground economy. Completely irrelevant, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The global underground economy, consisting mainly of tax evasion and criminal activities, but also terrorism, is much smaller than the legal economy (perhaps one-fifth the size), but it is still highly consequential.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Irrelevant! So it's all about whose currency is dominant. And they're saying a widely used, state-backed Chinese digital currency is already the standard.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Irrelevant! So it's all about whose currency is dominant. And they're saying a widely used, state-backed Chinese digital currency is already the standard.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And a widely used, state-backed Chinese digital currency could certainly have an impact, especially in areas where Chinas interests do not coincide with those of the West.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Already the standard! So, uh, a US-regulated digital currency? Totally useless. Why would North Korea use it, right? To hire scientists?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Already the standard! So, uh, a U S-regulated digital currency? Totally useless. Why would North Korea use it, right? To hire scientists?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A US-regulated digital currency could in principle be required to be traceable by US authorities, so that if North Korea were to use it to hire Russian nuclear scientists, or Iran were to use it to finance terrorist activity, they would run a high risk of being caught, and potentially even blocked.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Or Iran for, like, terrorist activity? The US wouldn't even know. Let alone stop them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Or Iran for, like, terrorist activity? The U S wouldn't even know. Let alone stop them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A US-regulated digital currency could in principle be required to be traceable by US authorities, so that if North Korea were to use it to hire Russian nuclear scientists, or Iran were to use it to finance terrorist activity, they would run a high risk of being caught, and potentially even blocked.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No chance! But if it's run out of China? Oh, the US would be forced to comply. Under pressure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No chance! But if it's run out of China? Oh, the U S would be forced to comply. Under pressure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If, however, the digital currency were run out of China, the US would have far fewer levers to pull. Western regulators could ultimately ban the use of Chinas digital currency...

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, under pressure from all other nations. And Western regulators? They couldn't even ban it. It would spread to the US and Europe within a week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, under pressure from all other nations. And Western regulators? They couldn't even ban it. It would spread to the U S and Europe within a week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Western regulators could ultimately ban the use of Chinas digital currency, but that wouldnt stop it from being used in large parts of Africa, Latin America, and Asia, which in turn could engender some underground demand even in the US and Europe.

dialogue_turns.text: Within a week! And Bitcoin, um, all those other cryptos? They're saying they're obsolete. Useless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Within a week! And Bitcoin, um, all those other cryptos? They're saying they're obsolete. Useless.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One might well ask why existing cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin cannot already perform this function. To an extremely limited extent, they do.

dialogue_turns.text: Useless! Because regulators worldwide have, like, removed all incentives to control them. They're already in China's hands anyway.
